Less convincing is the evidence for the view that »the Spartans won the great majority of the battles which they fought on land less on account of the superior training and physique of their own troops than as the result of good generalship« ( pp.  369! ? .  ) ; and in the discussion of the operations at Mantinea it is strange to find no mention either of W.  J.  Woodhouse's monograph on King Agis or of Kromayer's study of the battle - field. 
The view that Thucydides derived his knowledge of Spartan army - organisation from prisoners taken at Sphacteria is naturally incapable of proof,  and far from the only possible explanation of its source.  And to go further and assume »that the 292 prisoners ( from the island ) were vely questioned about their ages « may strike some readers as reckless. 
The discussion of the Enomotiae ( p.  389f.  ) might have been made briefer if the author had been acquainted with Toynbee's article in /.  H.  S,  1915,  in which the same conclusions are clearly stated.  The evolution of the tary organisation based on the three original Dorian tribes into a fourfold system,  with the Phratria replaced by the Enomotia,  is dated to the fifth century,  »most likely between 446 and 431 « ; but the evidence cited ( on p.  395 ) for the older system as still in force at the time of the Persian Wars seems unconvincing.  ( May we really regard the Delphi tripod - column with its three entwined snakes as »undoubtedly symbolising a predominantly Dorian army under Spartan leadership « ; and can the ocpic ; XQiéXiKXoç of the oracle [ ap,  Herod,  vi.  77 ] refer to the Spartan and not to the Argive army?  ) Finally,  if the new unit now comprised 32,  or,  in exceptional circumstances,  40 men in place of 27,  what are we to make of the corollary that before the change the age for release from military service was 49 years?  ( Were there no men of fifty or over at Plataea?  )

Chapter XI »The Main Stages in the Development of the Constitution « discusses in turn the Relation of the Spartan Kingship with the Homeric Monarchy ; the History of the Ephorate ; and the Nature of the Lycurgan Reforms.  The first section need not delay us long.  Its conclusion is that the double Kingship developed comparatively late out of the Homeric Monarchy,  in which no trace of joint rule on equal terms can be traced,  and that the change to a »diarchy « was a significant constitutional ment.  The Ephorate is discussed thoughtfully,  and few will object to the statements that it was a Dorian rather than a merely Spartan institution,  and that Ephors existed { pace Cleomenes III.  ) before the first Messenian War and practised other duties before they began to encroach on the judicial powers of the kings.  To account for their being five in number it is gested that two were in some way deputies of the kings and the other three originally attached to the three ( admittedly hypothetical ) ( pvXofiaxjiXeïç of 8
